page.title: 02Red Sandstone Quarry/Creca
page.content: Corsehill quarries were in use for 80 years before the Second World War supplying all the local free stone and exporting to Ireland, U.S.A., Sweden and Canada. High export tariffs and the cheapness of brick discouraged the use of stone. The people of Creca and Brydekirk depended on the quarry for employment. In 1982 the quarry was re-opened to build the National Portrait Gallery in Edinburgh. Recently stone has been shipped to Dubai for a sheik's palace. Many other buildings have stone from these quarries. The Lanes, Carlisle, the Clydesdale Bank, Ayr and various buildings have red sandstone facings. The quarry company is private and pays royalties per tonne to the Annan District Council. 3 or 4 men are employed.
